description.narrative: 4.1 Strengthened government capacity to implement and monitor inclusive youth policies for Lebanese and Non-Lebanese youth.,which contributes to Adolescent Empowerment, Children With Disabilities, Cross-Sectoral Adolescent Development, Cross-Sectoral Monitoring, Data And Situation Analyses, Economic And Social Policy General, Evaluation And Research, Skills Development, Social Protection. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: 4. By the end of 2020, the most disadvantaged youth (15-24) increasingly influence policies and engage in quality learning, employment, and healthy lifestyles.

mailing-address.narrative: Maamari Street Gefinor Center Block E 5th Floor Beirut

sector.narrative: Development of multi-sectoral legislation/policies/strategies/action plans supporting development and participation of adolescents
System strengthening - mainstreaming of skills development within national education/training system

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities social services (incl youth development and women+ children)

title.narrative: Lebanon Programme Strategy Note Theory of Change (Adolescent and Youth Development)
UNICEF Contract Awards through the UN Global Marketplace
Lebanon 2018 Annual Report on Results for Children

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: 4.1 Strengthened government capacity to implement and monitor inclusive youth policies for Lebanese and Non-Lebanese youth.

description.narrative: UNICEF continued to support government entities to ensure marginalized youth access improved services by implementing identified priorities in the TVET National Strategic Framework (TVET NSF), developing an Action Plan for the National Youth Policy (NYP), and rolling out the MEHE certified Youth Basic Literacy and Numeracy Package (YBLN). | Status:On-track | As-of Date:17/01/2020

title.narrative: 4.1.c % of educators employed in UNICEF- supported learning spaces whose teaching performance meets MEHE and other defined standards (including quality standards and normative frameworks, disability mainstreaming, life skills, innovation and mentorship, AAP, PSEA and GBV identification and safe referral)
4.1.a. # of key recommendations of the National Youth Policy initiated with concerned ministries
4.2.e- # of national agricultural institutional sites (MOA schools) supported for improved agricultural livelihoods
4.1.d - # of knowledge pieces on the situation of youth generated to support policy formulation and advocacy
4.1.b - Appropriate national curricula, frameworks, standards and policies reviewed and endorsed (youth NFE and TVET components) (RACE ii) (*LC3) [Education Output Indicator 2.3.b]

baseline.value: YBLN curricular framweork and learning materials developed &amp, TVET NFE roadmap available

target.value: 2020:YBLN NFE Framework developed, endorsed and used by all UNICEF partners working with youth
